#Melakmengi
L65_ideas = {
	start = {
		build_cost = -0.1
		land_morale = 0.1 #willingly goes to battle against monsters (trolls)
	}
	bonus = {
		tolerance_own = 2
	}
	trigger = {
		tag = L65 #Melakmengi
	}
	free = yes
	
	L65_legacy_of_zenidir = { # over the course of 500 years, Zenidir's rule saw the spread of the Yeteferen language across Madriamilak, which eventually evolved into the modern Mengi language. He sought to uplift the settle down the nomadic tribes of the land, directing the construction of numerous cities and settlements. He uplifting thousands to a better, more civilized life. With Melakmengi reborn, we will do the same as he did, and seek to better the lives of all of Amilak's subjects.
		years_of_nationalism = -5
	}
	L65_the_semayebaka_society = { # mages are very prominent in mengi society and governance due to their religious importance. In Melakmengi, they are quite influential in governance too. Much of Melakmengi's government is made up of Semayebaka, who are all mages. Through the institution of the Semayebaka Society, the mages of Melakmengi can be directed to serve the interests of the state more effectively.
		mages_loyalty_modifier = 0.1
	}
	L65_an_end_to_the_trollish_menace = { # artillery go boom! Embraces the technology and improves upon it and make their own. Artillery corps becomes own section of army. What finally allows the mengi to push into the shadowswamp. The Sarhal tag that likes arty the most (unless bulwar counts)
		artillery_power = 0.15
	}
	L65_god_of_the_skies = { # reforms to their faith, and seek to convert others to the worship of Amilak, the god of the skies. Expansionistic outlook
		missionaries = 1
		manpower_in_true_faith_provinces = 0.15
	}
	L65_order_of_rains = { # section of the semayebaka society that performs the holy duties of summoning the rains. The farm fields regularly receive rains with timetables scheduled months in advance, streamlined with an education system that produces masses of cloud priests. The result is very large crop yields, allowing even the poorest mengi to be well fed
		development_cost = -0.15
	}
	L65_a_new_administration_for_a_new_empire = { # melakmengi creates a new bureaucratic state largely inspired by Rahen and Yanshen, which the state uses to weaken the old nobility and ultimately end Mengi feudalism in Madriamilak.
		governing_capacity_modifier = 0.15
	}
	L65_the_nagide_monopoly = { # limits cannorian traders to a few ports (mainly yetmesira and dakmender), think cohong monopoly. Nagide merchant companies need a license/contract to do business with foreign traders
		trade_efficiency = 0.10
	}
}

B76_ideas = {

		cavalry_cost = -0.15 
		global_tax_modifier = 0.1
	}

		improve_relation_modifier = 0.15
	}
	trigger = {
		tag = B76 #Horsegarden
	}
	free = yes
	
	B76_the_first_spear = { # Popular Lencori tale about an avatar of Adean, Artanos, that led a group of riders in a fight against serpentine monsters that came from the sea. Some of the people saved by the riders founded the town of Horsegarden and used the avatar's magical spear to build a shrine to honor his memory called the First Spear.
		cavalry_power = 0.15
	}
	B76_a_horse_for_every_lord = { # Horse breeding is a common activity throughout Horsegarden. These horse breeders have perfected their craft for generations, to the point that Horsegarden is now known as the best place to get a horse and attract the rich and powerful men and women of Cannor in need of a mount for themself or their armies. This position in the horse trade gave some renown to Horsegarden and made its horse breeders rich.
		production_efficiency = 0.1
		prestige = 0.5
	}
	B76_peasant_lords = { # The nobility of Horsegarden is close to the peasantry, they work together, and the lords take the most skilled commoner as advisor. This led to many horsegarden commoner becoming notable figure within Lencori history like Avery the Smith, or El�anore �Goldweaver� who thanks to the duke's advice, worked for the royal family.
		same_culture_advisor_cost = -0.1
		advisor_pool = 1
	}
	B76_along_the_spears_way = { # The Spear Way is the main road taken by pilgrims to Adeanscour. Along the road are shrines dedicated to Adean and honoring knights that have accomplished great deeds. These shrines all include as a central element a spear pointing to the sky.
		land_morale = 0.1 
	}
	B76_a_wound_reopens = { # The count of Saddleglade sided with Elizar and betrayed the crown, hoping to carve out his own realm out of Lorent. He take Horsegarden by surprise, the ducal family is murder and food was seized in an attempt to starve the rebellious horsegardener into submission, creating a famine in the duchy. After the event, steps were taken by the people to prevent it from happening again, from building fortification to organizing militia, but were slowly abandoned over time. The Lilac Wars brought back devastation to Horsegarden and promise to bring more, efforts were made to restore and modernize the defenses of the land.
		defensiveness = 0.1
	}
	B76_twin_festivities = { # Originally two distinct festivals celebrating Eilis and Madalein, became one after reunification of the duchy of Horsegarden as a festival of unity. During the festival, a joust and horseback races are organized, followed by feasts and magic shows. 
		legitimacy = 1
		devotion = 1
		republican_tradition = 0.3
		horde_unity = 1
	}
	B76_the_order_of_errants = { # Religious order devoted to Adean that roam the countryside and fight bandits. It is composed of 2 branches, a secular one and a religious one. The religious branch helps with the maintenance of the wayside shrines of Lencenor. As other orders were seen as more appealing, the errants were poorly funded and low in number until the nobles and rich horse breeders of Horsegarden agreed to fund and supply them.
		global_unrest = -2
		church_loyalty_modifier = 0.05
	}
}

		caravan_power = 0.20 #Control over the pass of important trade routes.

		manpower_in_true_faith_provinces = 0.15 #Acceptance of anyone that follows the Jadd.
	}

	trigger = {
		tag = F92 #Taladzan
	}
	free = yes

	F92_together_under_the_sun = { # After the humans came back to the lands that they called theirs only to find us living there many conflicts erupted, it was only after we saw the light that we understood that coexisting was better than conflicting.
		num_accepted_cultures = 2 
	}
	F92_bricks_grandmasters = { #taladzan is the backbone of the azka-sur construction sector, from the mixing of the powder used to make the bricks to the curing of the brick everything is done in taladzan.
	build_cost = -0.1		
	}
	F92_salt_gastronomes = { #Salt is very loved in taladzan, so loved that people will try all possible foods with it, whether they are meat or fruit.
		idea_cost = -0.1
	}
	F92_camel_husbandry = { #Many hyenas were brought during the rule of zokka, it was discovered that animals including The Rubisum, a species of camel known for their shaggy coat that falls every summer and regrows over-time, started easily listening to orders while close to them, this led to many gnolls to start taming and producing wool with camels.
		production_efficiency = 0.10 
	}
	F92_twin_forts_of_jikarzax = { #Two brothers in charge of building a fort in Jikarzax, origin of the Bituzan river, could not decide whether to build it on top or on the bottom of the mountain, they decided to do both.
		defensiveness = 0.20
	}
	F92_until_the_blaze_stops_you = { #Dancing under the sun is a very stupid thing to do, in Taladzan it has become a tradition to see who can last the longest before collapsing.
		land_attrition = -0.15		
	}
	F92_the_saqann_nevad = { #Azka-sur ruler sent an administrator to taladzan, when he gained the locals respect they started calling him saqann nevad, as he was about to pass away he granted it to the gnolls as a sign that their differences were a past story.
		prestige = 1
	}

}

	start = {
		hostile_attrition = 1 #Yanglam shared tradition
      	shock_damage_received = -0.1 #Yanglam shared tradition
	}
	
	bonus = {
		cavalry_power = 0.15 #Peak use of eagle riders in armies
	}
	
	trigger = {
		tag = Y80 #Menek Poko
	}
	free = yes
	
	Y80_tree_towns = { #The Menek Poko really like the forest and its spirits, so they build their houses on the trees both to be resource efficient and as a sign of veneration to the forest, as they believe this way they are the closest to its spirits and the Lupuan.
		build_cost = -0.05
		development_cost = -0.05
	}
	Y80_natures_advice = { #To seek the advice of the tree spirits, the Menek Poko put their heads inside tree holes and wait for the spirits' advice. Those who get answers are seen as blessed and are searched for as advisors.
		same_culture_advisor_cost = -0.15
	}
	Y80_the_eagle_riders = { #Brave warriors steal the eggs of the great eagles of the Lupuan and train them to use as cavalry. The Menek Poko are very good at this because of their athleticism, so they can use a lot of them.
		cavalry_cost = -0.1
		leader_land_manuever = 1
	}
	Y80_offers_to_the_Lupulan = { #Because the Lupuan is considered to be alive, people put trinkets on the trees that they live on as an offering. Sometimes the spirits steal these offerings, and it is seen as a sign of good fortune and it is celebrated.
		global_unrest = -2
	}
	Y80_the_Ti_Ong = { #Some eagle riders really liked the sky instead of the forest, so they go to Feiten to try their ariships. They become really good pilots and gain the nickname Ti Ong (master of the sky).
		prestige = 1
	}
	Y80_yanglam_festival_of_the_sky = { #Festival pertaining to specific tag, modifier is the same for all. Shared modifier, unique loc.
        stability_cost_modifier = -0.15 #Baseline
    }
	yanglam_community_of_spirits_and_humans = { #All tribes learn to live in tandem with the spirits, this makes us well versed with spiritkind and very adaptable. Shared idea.
        reform_progress_growth = 0.15 #Baseline
    }
}

#Ethanamara
G78_ideas = {
	start = {
	    legitimacy = 1
        devotion = 1 
        horde_unity = 1 
        republican_tradition = 0.3  #Consider themselves rightful rulers of the Advakhalla and have a court culture.
        diplomatic_upkeep = 1 #Prefers a network of vassals to direct conquest.
	}
	
	bonus = {
		yearly_absolutism = 1 #Their courtly culture and paternalistic view of other people translates to absolute rule later on in the timeline.
    }
	
	trigger = {
		tag = G78 #Ethanamara
	}
	free = yes


	G78_khalla_nanri = {
	    diplomatic_reputation = 1 #Ethanamara is known as "Khalla Nanri", or stone clan, to the Advakhalla. It has acted as a mediator between the various Advakhalla clans, the greatest of which are Sedregenhi and Ahartadyam, and has always had ambitions of diplomatically subjugating the entirety of the Advakhalla people. (Khalla Nanri would be Ethanamara's regional rename)
	}
   	G78_our_lowland_brethren = {
	    improve_relation_modifier = 0.2 #While Ethanamara is a mediating force between the Advakhalla, it is also the only Advakhalla state to have mildly peaceful relations with the lowlands Larankarha, trying to soothe the bitter rivalries the two people have due to centuries of mutual raids and conquests. They have a paternalistic vision of both the other Advakhalla and the lowland Larankarha, thinking them as wayward brethren to enlighten in the ways of the Thousand Paths of Stone.
	}
	G78_the_high_court = {
		all_estate_loyalty_equilibrium = 0.05 #The Ethanamari, along with their diplomatic ties to the Advakhalla and Larankarha, are known for their courtly culture. The High Court of Ethanamara (partly named so due to its geographical height), located in their capital of Ethanan, is known for its beauty and the high manners of the courtiers, something one wouldn't expect from the tribal Advakhalla. The throne room is filled with impressive stone and copper (from Sedregenhi) works, and the throne itself is made out of ivory from Anakal tusks.
	}
	G78_masters_of_kattyam = {
	    cavalry_shock = 0.1
 		cavalry_power = 0.15 #The Ethanamari are masters in the art of Taychendi bladedancing, widely known as Kattyam. Ethanamari riders are known as terrible foes : sturdy Larankarha horses are only more deadly if their rider can simply cut through the mass of the enemy army like butter. (This might be a Taychendi version of Diranbe, just Taychendi using swords as spellcasting focus but in a way that is NOT Diranbe or just Taychendi being adept with swords depending on the conclusions from the lore development thread)
	}
	G78_anakal_fellers = {
	    prestige = 1 #The Anakal are ferocious beasts hunted for their tusks, which are prized due to being one of the only sources of ivory in Taychend. Their highland variety lives primarily in the Advakhalla highlands, and Ethanamari hunters in particular have made it their pride to be masters in the hunt of these animals.
	}
	G78_people_of_the_peaks = {
	    advisor_cost = -0.15 #The Sikarhanal, or People of the Peaks, are the Taychendi people living in the Veyii Sikarha. Having never left the high mountains after the Ruin of Aelantir, they live simple herding lives but have a vibrant culture. Their religious traditions are completely distinct to those of the rest of Taychend. Most of Sikarhanal society is concentrated around a river valley facing the Effelai, but they often cross the mountains to come into Taychend. Ethanamara has generally had a friendly relationship with the Sikarhanal, their people being often prized as advisors due to their exotic and esoteric knowledge.
	}
	G78_the_thousand_paths_of_stone = {
	    tolerance_own = 2 #Ethanamara's local version of the Taychendi Hero Cults is heavily influenced by the Sikarhanal's Thousand Paths of Stone, a religion completely distinct from the other Taychendi faiths. While the Ethanamari did not assimilate the animist parts of the Sikarhanal religion, they do share their core belief of Enlightenment. To both the Sikarhanal and the Ethanamari, the ultimate state of the living being is Enlightenment, where after a series of rituals and tests notably involving meditation and introspection, one may become Enlightened and change into stone. For the Sikarhanal, no one has managed Enlightenment yet, but the Ethanamari integrate the belief into the mainstream Taychendi Hero Cults by believing that the Enlightened become superior gods to the simple warlord god heroes of the rest of Taychend and have already consigned a handful of Enlightened god heroes shown in a room of the High Court. The Enlightenments in Ethanamara are notably made possible by the Pebbles from Beyond the Light, a series of Precursor relics found in Ethanan. The original purpose of these small, round objects has been lost to time, but they hold great transmutation powers, allowing the petrification rituals central in the Thousand Paths of Stone to take place.
	}
}

#Korrimutren
G83_ideas = {
	start = {
	    prestige_decay = -0.01 #The Oracle of Korrimutren is famous and religiously significant in all of Taychend.
        global_tax_modifier = 0.1 #Major pilgrimage destination.
	}
	
	bonus = {
		global_missionary_strength = 0.02 #They spread Kheionism to the other Taychendi, helped by the Threadbearer's importance.
    }
	
	trigger = {
		tag = G83 #Korrimutren
	}
	free = yes

	G83_the_fateweaver = {
	    missionaries = 1 #In a great chamber beneath Korrimutren can be found the corpse of Kanelethiel the Fateweaver. Kanelethiel was a Precursor slaver-noble with incredible divination powers, which she enhanced using an immense relic (see Taka diagram)i. Merely a few hours before the DoAS, Kanelethiel predicted the catastrophe. In a desperate attempt to try to survive the Ruin, she locked herself within the Oracle chamber and started a ritual to transfer her soul to the relic. Whether the ritual went to plan or not is unknown, but the end result is clear � should someone with sufficient divination ability touch the corpse of the Fateweaver that lies beneath the relic, they will be able to commune with her and receive the power of prophecy. The Taychendi consider the Fateweaver a god hero and the hero-cults worshiping her are widespread in Thektoram, Oremvand and southern Yodhanchend. The most important of these cults, the Followers of the Threadbearer, is based in Korrimutren itself and is composed mostly of diviners and oracles. The leader of this cult, the Threadbearer, is allowed to communicate with the Fateweaver to gain visions and deliver prophecies. Threadbearers are chosen for their own exceptional divination ability, required for handling the immense magics of the Fateweaver � should a lay person touch the Fateweaver's corpse, it will likely have explosive results. The Threadbearer is by far the most important oracle in Taychend, and Korrimutren is an important pilgrimage center due to people from all corners of the region desiring to receive prophecies.
	}
	G83_darakash_the_threadsworm = {
	    land_morale = 0.1 #Darakash the Threadsworn was a pious follower of the Threadbearer, renowned philosopher and brilliant general having distinguished himself during the war against Kadradar and gaining popularity among veterans across southern Taychend by doing so. In 867, Darakash visited the Threadbearer and received a prophecy that would forever change Taychend's history :  �You will lead the greatest host the world has ever known, and from the lands of the setting sun you will create an empire greater than those of Ebenanth and Yodhan." Tired of the pride and ambition of Taychend and given faith in his vision by the prophecy, Darakash rallied an immense host composed of veterans from the Stormbringer's War and their families and launched a great expedition into the Chendhyan steppes in 869. The expedition would with difficulty carve a path through the Chendhya in a strict and overly-technical march through the region, often fighting against the Chendhyan tribes seeing it as an invasion of their homes. After an arduous journey, the expedition reached the borders of the Nekheis of Empkheios in 873 and settled in the great open plains of the Devand, founding the philosopher kingdom of Vadhipakvam. The organization of Vadhipakvam was designed around the philosophical ideals of Darakash. While Kheionai traders had been present in Taychend for a few hundred years now, this was the first true large-scale contact between both civilizations. Meanwhile, the Chendhyans grew resentful of the Taychendi due the trail of death the expedition had left behind. Using their newly kindled hate of the Taychendi, the Chendhyan chief Ultarlanbeg would push for the tribes' unification, forming the Saerraeg Asaedzudar in 897. The first targets of the Chendhyans were Vadhipakvam and Empkheios, and the short-lived Taychendi kingdom was completely destroyed by Ultarlanbeg. The few surviving Taychendi from Vadhipakvam would spread out in the Nekheis and integrate into Kheionai society, and even today substantial minorities of beard-growing Kheionai exist in Keyolion and Eneion. (Vadhipakvam would be Korrimutren's regional rename)
	}
   	G83_shards_of_clairvoyance = {
	    tolerance_own = 2 #The Korrimutreni are renowned glassblowers. Their signature glass, the Glass of Clairvoyance, is named so due to both its impressive clarity and its extensive use in the divination rituals of oracles throughout Taychend due to its association with the Fateweaver. It is said that looking at a person through shards of this glass or disposing it in certain patterns can help diviners focus and obtain clearer visions.
	}
	G83_the_giants_vale = {
	    defensiveness = 0.15 #The city of Korrimutren is located in a valley, cornered on all sides by rolling hills and its southern portion facing the great sea. The position is one of the most defensible in Taychend, as fortifications line the surrounding hills while supplies can be transported by the sea if a siege ever came to befell the city. While the Taychendi are familiar with the high peaks of the Veyii Sikarha, the hills of Thektoram have always been mysterious to them due to their poor understanding of their formation, so a popular legend exists, talking about how these hills are actually gigantic burial mounds constructed by ancient giants who once roamed Halann. (this myth comes from vague cultural memories of the giants who were known by the Precursors)
	}
	G83_pelojiths_sacrifice = {
	    war_exhaustion = -0.03             
        global_garrison_growth = 0.1 #Merely a decade before Laskaris' invasion, Zaernmaera went on a conquest spree under the rule of Zaernsarax, becoming the biggest power of the Guaraddhi. However, Zaernsarax's ambitions were greater than merely ruling over the poor steppes of the region. Hence, he set his gaze east, leading his cat rider army into the hills of Korrimutren. The defenders were quickly defeated, but one obstacle stayed between Zaernsarax and his dreams of grand conquests : the Giants' Mounds. The Zearnmaerae army was stopped at the city of Korrimutren and were forced to lay siege to it. The siege lasted a staggering 4 years, but the defenders were starting to see their numbers dwindle and the city was at threat of falling to the enemy. This was when the Threadbearer delivered a prophecy to Teshapin, the ruler of Korrimutren, that he would lead an attack and decisively win against the attackers. Teshapin rallied the garrison of the city and sallied out to face the Zaernmaerae, and despite his poor military skills and being outnumbered the attackers were forced to flee back to the Guaraddhi, partly due to the zeal the prophecy had given to the soldiers.
	}
	G83_the_first_followers = {
	    diplomatic_reputation = 1 #After Laskaris dealt a devastating blow to Gophira, Tirsin, Sthanan ith Vussam, Nagar Vyechei and even seizing the coastal city of Anakal, Korrimutren quickly swore fealty to Ameion, heavily influenced by the Threadbearer's prophecy. While this move was initially taken in fear of conquest from Ameion, Korrimutren quickly became zealously loyal to Laskaris and his cause.
	}
	G83_cradle_of_civilization = {
	    culture_conversion_cost = -0.2 #Like Korrimutren was the first Taychendi state to kneel before Laskaris, it was where the culture and religion of the Kheionai first spread into the land of warlords. Korrimutren was instrumental in the spreading of Klereyen culture across Taychend and the local Klereyen consider themselves superior to the rest of the Taychendi due to being, in their words, the cradle of true civilization in Taychend.
	}
}

#Sarihaddu
J71_ideas = {
	start = {
		tolerance_own = 2 #Unusually high number of god heroes.
		army_tradition = 0.5 #Constant infighting between the tribes and conflicts with the surrounding states.
	}
	
	bonus = {
		production_efficiency = 0.1 #To push the idea of the desert becoming more and more prosperous under Ameion�s rule after the activation of the Dust Tear.
    }
	
	trigger = {
		tag = J71 #Sarihaddu
	}
	free = yes


	J71_four_tribes_of_the_sarihaddu = {
		land_forcelimit_modifier = 0.2 #The Sarihaddi people are not centered around a single city-state unlike the rest of Taychend due to their home�s hostile environment. Instead, their society is organized by the Four Tribes of the Sarihaddu. They are very divided, constantly fighting among themselves and are only united in times of foreign wars, be it during one of the Thousand Raids or protecting against invaders. These tribes are the Kirenur, the Veaddi, the Vaeyusid and the Sattaerut. The Kirenur are the most traditional and religious of the tribes, keeping the Dust Graveyard under their custody. The Veaddi are the most warlike and powerful of the four tribes due to Varamaezh�s legacy. The Vaeyusid were mostly looked upon throughout history and would be the most acceptant of Kheionai rule and become the most powerful tribe after the activation of the Dust Tear. The Sattearut are the most Chendhyan-influenced and the most fervently Chainbreaker, with many of the Sarihaddi lieutenants of Ultarlanbeg being members of the Sattearut tribe. (once the time for that kind of stuff comes it could be interesting to have them be a unique gov reform with factions and unique ruler succession)
	}
   	J71_the_dust_graveyard = {
		same_culture_advisor_cost = -0.15 #At the very center of the desert, buried within the sands lies a mesmerizing structure : the Dust Graveyard. It is built upon a precursor ruin, and is home to many still intact relics, though the Sarihaddi prefer to preserve them and never use them due to superstitions and traditions. The many god heroes of the Sarihaddu are buried there, with the central and largest tomb being taken by Varamaezh the Windwaker. The idea insists on the fact that the Sarihaddi are not just chendhyanized Taychendi, but a complete cultural isolate with their own traditions, practices and language.
	}
	J71_ultarlanbegs_acolytes = {
		leader_land_shock = 1 #When Ultarlanbeg invaded Taychend, the Sarihaddu willingly joined the horde due to their links with the Chendyans. They played a key role to the success of the Asaedzudar as lieutenants of his armies due to their knowledge of Taychendi tactics. After the collapse of the Asaedzudar the Sarihaddu took on a fervently Chainbreaker stance uniquely for Taychendi, though that did not stop them from repeatedly raiding Caegaeren.
	}
	J71_varamaezh_the_windwaker = {
		hostile_attrition = 1 #Despite god heroes being way more common in Sarihaddi society, Sarihaddu still has a main god hero. Hailing from the Veaddi tribe, Varamaezh (Varamesh from the Yodhanpir namelist but chendhyanized) united the Sarihaddi against Gophira during the rise of the Second Gophiran Empire, using his knowledge of the desert to tire their armies before dealing swift but annihilating blows. He notably used sandstorms to his advantage, becoming known as �the Windwaker� as his people started to believe he could literally summon storms to weaken his enemies. He allowed the Sarihaddi to never be truly subjugated by Gophira, even with the rest of Taychend under their firm grasp.
	}
	J71_the_thousand_raids = {
		loot_amount = 0.5 #The Sarihaddi are very familiar with the rise and fall cycle of Taychend, though in a unique manner compared to the rest of the region. While most of the Four Tribes� time is spent during conflicts between them, from small skirmishes to blown out wars, these periods of infighting are often cut off by the rise of a god hero who will unite the Sarihaddi and go on a great raiding campaign on a bordering Yodhanpir, Larankarha or Chendhyan polity. These raids are commonly referred to as the Thousand Raids by themselves and their neighbors due to their incessant nature. They are the main reason why the Sarihaddi worship so many different god heroes.
	}
	J71_shattered_chains_of_haenbuddar = {
		global_unrest = -2 #The Sarihaddi revolt from Ameion�s empire in 1612, taking advantage of the devastating Prophet�s War. They then establish their only lasting state (lasting meaning 13 years long) outside their home desert and conquer around three quarters of the Western Frontier, sacking many centers of the slave trade, most notably Haenbuddar. They get reconquered by Ameion in 1625 but deal a great damage to the slave trade, weakening Ameion�s vassal Rakkabuttai and finally cementing Ameion�s turn away from slavery. While their state was destroyed, they ended up dragging one of their biggest rivals with them. This state was called Kirchaend, or Dust Land in Sarihaddi (Adilabad Gondi with some Yodhanpir and Chendhyan influence) and was led by Daraxam Sattearut. Kirchaend would be Sarihaddu�s regional rename.
	}
	J71_where_the_desert_blooms = {
		development_cost_in_primary_culture = -0.1 #After the fall of Kirchaend, the Sarihaddu desert was firmly in the hands of Ameion. They conduct their archaeology projects there due to the large deposits of Precursor Relics the Dust Graveyard and its surroundings contain. There, they find what would be called �the Dust Tear�, an extremely powerful relic which upon accidental activation by the researchers seemingly completely altered the area�s climate as rainfall became increasingly common and the very sand took on the properties of fertile soil. The Dust Tear crumbled into dust a few hours after its activation, before its effects could even be noticed. After a few years, vegetation already started to spread to the once-desert. The climate reverted to normal a few decades, most likely due to the relic having been damaged after the DoAS, but it did massively impact the area�s politics as the Vaeyusid gained a lot of power, the Sarihaddi started to rely less on raids for their survival and kheionization progressed well in the area. (just a thought since this idea talks about Ameion, maybe the Sarihaddi which get successfully kheionized could have a spread between becoming Klereyen, Kheionized Taychendi, and Astolbhen, Kheionized Devandi)
	}
}

#Parahechend
J81_ideas = {
	start = {
		diplomatic_upkeep = 1 #Has been a subject for most of their history.
		cavalry_cost = -0.15 #Necessary modifier if we want small tags to use cavalry. Also they have the material to equip their cavalry due to scavenging.
	}
	
	bonus = {
		yearly_absolutism = 1 #Legacy of Varelrudu the Puppeteer and Veliara the White Queen.
	}
	
	trigger = {
		tag = J81 #Parahechend
	}
	free = yes

	J81_the_field_of_ruins = {
		prestige = 1 #Parahechend is the place of many battles, serving as the main vanguard between the Larankarha barbarians and Nanru Nakar. Its inhabitants are known stalwart defenders and throughout the lands can be found many ancient battlefields where Kalavendi and Larankarha forces clashed. From precursor ruins to old battlefields and ruins from Rakulacimai, Parahechend�s lands look more like a giant archeology site than an actual countryside. Parahechend�s population is particularly nostalgic of the older times, as they are constantly surrounded by reminders of the area�s past glory while they toil its poor soil. The Scavenger Guilds always had influence in Parahechend due to the area�s perfect nature for their operations. After the reunification of Nanru Nakar this influence only grew and Parahechend was finally acknowledged by them for its significance. They became a major part of the local politics and were commonly called �the Outsider Guilds� due to both working on the open sky (unlike Nanru Nakar�s guilds) and coming from outside of Parahechend.
	}
	J81_the_tyrant_king_of_pirisitel = {
		harsh_treatment_cost = -0.25 #Parahechend�s god hero. The closest advisor of the teenage emperor Tailananth Mudaliar, Varelrudu the Puppeteer was the real power behind the throne during his rule, controlling the emperor�s every move in the shadows. He was extremely tyrannous and cruel. A perfect example of this was Vehasha�s rebellion, where he personally killed the rebel leader in battle and commanded vast executions of the prisoners. After the rebellion he put the failing mudaliar emperor back together with force and harsh reprisals � he put cities to the sword, killed and enslaved the entire noble/elite classes of certain cities, etc etc. Assyrians putting down revolts style. His name is basically a by-word for ruthless surpression.
	}
	J81_the_shadow_kingdom = {
		ae_impact = -0.15 #After the Mudaliar Empire collapses for good the son of Varelrudu, Geledish, who inherited his father�s role of puppeteer, decided to take more radical actions. He coldbloodedly killed Tailananth and took over the Mudaliar remnants, founding Rakulacimai, the Shadow Kingdom, and the Rakulacan dynasty. Geledish and his descendants started to suck Nanru Nakar�s power for the good of Pirsitel (which Geledish renamed to Nanru Pirsitel since in his mind it is the only city deserving the �Great� adjective). This would not last long however, as a Mudaliar rebellion regained control over Nanru Nakar and razed Pirsitel to the ground. After this time the area�s seat of power would shift to Parahechend and the nation would never know independence again. 
	}
	J81_scythed_chariots = {
        cavalry_shock = 0.25  #The drylands of Parahechend weren�t the heartlands of either form of Rakulacimai, but they are known throughout Taychend for their swift, agile and docile horses. One of the most known Parahechendi military units are the Scythed Chariots, terrifying machines of war which cut through infantry formations like butter, especially unarmoured and undisciplined peasant levies.
	}
	J81_veliara_the_white_queen = {
		stability_cost_modifier = -0.15 #In the 1730s, Nanru Nakar�s empire in the Kalavend collapsed under the pressure of Enlarmai and Parahechendi revolts. In charge of Parahechend was Veliara the White Queen, a Taychendi name taken by Mihaela, a long-time Cannorian ally of the Rakulacan. Veliara conquered the Kalavend with the support of the Rakulacan and claimed to have found a relic granting her and her followers immortality, fashioning herself as another of the Relic Lords. This new Kalavendhi empire became known as �Rakulacimai�, after the old empire of the Rakulacans. However, there was no immortality relic. Unknown to her own people, Veliara was a particularly powerful second-generation vampire and had been spreading her curse among the Rakulacan dynasty and their military commanders. Instead of trying to destroy Taychendi society, Veliara simply decided to put herself on top of it, taking the instability following a warlord's death out of the equation and proclaiming herself an immortal god.
	}
	J81_the_war_rigs = {
		cavalry_power = 0.15 #Parehechend develops chariot technicals under the reign of Veliara using knowledge of artificery both stolen from the Vustarin and gained from Veliara's cannorian contacts. These are beefed up, armored chariots that have mounted small guns on them etc. Real Mad Max vibe.
	}
	J81_repaid_in_blood = {
		general_cost = -0.15 #Although the Kalavend knew unprecedented stability during the rule of Veliara, fate would not smile to her for long. The Blood Court, an international organization of vampires, had lost track of Mihaela since her flight during the 1600s, but were not particularly frightened by her existence. This changed when she revealed herself as Veliara in the 1730s, as the Blood Court quickly realized the true nature of Parahechend and how dangerous a Taychendi vampire kingdom could be to their precious secrecy. Leveraging their influence and wealth, the Blood Court entices thousands of Cannorian mercenaries and adventurers to flood the Kalavend, including many Ravelian missionaries who start preaching to the local Taychendi. This is the start of an hidden, unofficial war between the Blood Court and Parahechend, which reaches its climax in 1787 as Royakottar revolts against Parahechend, aided by Ameion and Rezankand. While Ameion collapses shortly afterwards and Parahechend wins the initial battles of the war, putting Royakottar under siege, it all falls down in 1794 as Nanru Nakar revolts in turn, this time with the aid of the unexpected alliance of the Blood Court and the Ravelian Church. As Parahechend collapses, the desperate Rakulacan try to trap Veliara to save their skin, but she manages to escape and goes into hiding. Even after the collapse of Parahechend, the Kalavend is infested with hundreds of vampires.
	}
}

		leader_land_manuever = 1 #Varamrayan warfare, like much of its other aspects, is defined by the great Kalavend river. 	}

Uratand . While on the outside he showed a mask of friendliness and genuine diplomatic intentions, on the inside he was a cold calculator, organizing political assassinations to destabilize other countries or using spies to blackmail and threaten the great powers of the region, sometimes leading some of these operations himself despite the danger of being caught. When the Nakari inevitably came knocking on Varamraya�s door, the generals who hadn�t mysteriously died defected to Varamraya along with significant portions of the army, allowing the state to survive until the Second Gophiran Empire conquered Taychend.
	}

	J82_skirmish_under_the_sun = {
		hostile_attrition = 1 #In the mid 1600s (1640s-ish), Rezankand tries for the third time to conquer into taychend, confident in victory now that Ameion has left and the Kamrayakval's war has ravaged all of taychend. Much like the iron cities of Gophira, Banderuttai and Kattisangamar hold a near-total monopoly over Taychend�s iron, Sedregenhi is widely known for holding a great part of the region�s copper production, though due to their isolation their importance in trade is much lesser. 	}
	G65_the_seven_grand_copper_mines = {
	    burghers_loyalty_modifier = 0.1 #Originally built as mining settlements by the Precursor Empire, the Seven Copper Mines are the hearts of life in Sedregenhi. 	}
	G65_the_tranquil_people = {
	    global_unrest = -2 #The Sedregenha are often called the Tranquil People by the rest of the Taychendi, due to not really being interested in warfare unlike most of their kin. 	}
	G65_armorgrinders = {
	    shock_damage = 0.1 #While not a warrior people, the Sedregenhi have often been invaded or raided by the peoples of the lowlands. 	}
	G65_abenharons_peace = {
	    num_accepted_cultures = 1
        idea_cost = -0.05 #After the Dugui�hi were expelled out of the Mushroom Forest, not all of them stayed inside the bounds of Airoa Naditari. This Dugui�hi population was initially distrusted and even mistreated by the Advakhalla due to their foreign customs. However, this changed when Ab�nharon came to rule Sedregenhi. While not a great fighter, Ab�nharon was able to mend relations between the Dugui�hi and Advakhalla, taking a Dugui�hi consort in proof of good faith.
	}
	G65_a_mine_of_mushrooms = {
	    global_trade_power = 0.1 #After being properly integrated in Sedregenhi, the Dugui�hi started to concentrate and create an entirely new �Copper Mine� of their own, though it is often called the Eighth due to the relatively poor concentration of copper under the city. While the underground part of the other Copper Mines were mostly used for (obviously) mining copper, in the Eighth�s underground large scale fungiculture happened, as the adept with mushrooms Dugui�hi mixed their experience with the Sedregenhi�s expertise of the underground, allowing exotic mushrooms to be grown and traded for their medical and psychedelic attributes.
	}

	    monthly_splendor = 1 
	    prestige = 1 #After the DoAS, the Endioka river valley quickly became one of the centers of Taychendi civilization, many prosperous cities springing up in the region during the few centuries following the Ruin of Aelantir. Enlarmai was notably founded as a Kalavendhi military colony by Ebenanth before it was taken over by the Larankarha after the collapse of his empire, explaining why the name is in Kalavendhi. Over the years, the importance of the Endioka river valley slowly reduced in favor of places like the Kalavend, the Iron Cities or the Vyech River, and the great cities of the region such as Imarti Sadvya, Sithra Calindash or Aidkalenti were gradually left to disrepair, gaining the appellation �Ruin Cities�. However, Enlarmai managed to keep the prosperity of the ancient times and avoid the fate of its equals, remaining one of the most powerful cities of Taychend until the 15th century.
	}
	G72_the_eight_kingdoms = {
	    ae_impact = -0.1 #Throughout the centuries, the Larankarha have been united seven times by the kingdom of Larankar, formed by the various Larankarha city-states. However, Enlarmai was the capital of the greatest one, the second kingdom of Larankar, and it has kept a lot of legitimacy from this time. The first kingdom was formed by Sithra Calindash in response to the fall of Ebenanth�s Empire during the Age of Strife. It allowed the region to prosper and the many cities on the Endioka to flourish, before falling to Yodhan. The second kingdom was formed by Enlarmai in similar circumstances as the first empire, forming after the fall of Yodhan�s Empire. It was by far the longest-lived, its duration spanning the Second Age of Ambition, the Mudaliar Empire which they were a vassal of and the first few decades of the Third Age of Ambition. Its collapse in 458 after a civil war would mark the true start of warlordism in the Endioka river valley and the slow fall of the Ruin Cities. The third and fourth kingdoms existed in short succession from 639 to 662 and are generally remembered as weak and irrelevant. They were formed by Enlarmai and Urvand respectively. The fifth kingdom was founded by Seronraha the Marauder in 713 and would be dissolved when he died in 748. The sixth kingdom was formed when Marhed Rayodana conquered the lowland Larankarha in 811, and ruled  to its destruction by Kadradar in 864. Finally, the seventh kingdom actually started as a Chendhyan remnant Aedzudar of Ultarlanbeg�s conquests, with its capital in Tirsi Ebenesh, but the Chendhyan leadership was overthrown within a decade of the fall of the Asaedzudar, as the region was where the Chendhyans had the most tenuous control. Like the second kingdom, it was one of the most stable Larankarha kingdoms � surviving a brief subjugation by Olhokar intact � and brought great prosperity to the region, but it fell in 1228 in a destructive war against the Great Gophiran Empire. (Larankar would be Enlarmai�s regional rename. Disattararam, Ninth Kingdom, could work as well if we don�t want to have tags share regional renames)
	}
	G72_seronraha_the_marauder = {
	    loot_amount = 0.5 #Seronraha the Marauder ruled over Enlarmai during the 8th century. He would lead the city on a conquest spree, founding the sixth kingdom of Larankar. After this proclamation, he started to look southwards, something most Larankarha kingdom never did in history, as though raiding parties into the Kalavend and Yodhanchend were common even when the Larankarha weren�t unified, they never dared to try to properly conquer outside of their ancestral homes. Under the rule of Seronraha, the sixth kingdom of Larankar conquered Mahred Varanya, Kattisangamar and Banderuttai and the upper Kalavend. Seronraha is notable for his astonishing victory at Parahechend and subsequent sack of Nanru Nakar, which earned him the title of the Marauder. He would die of old age in 748, leading to the fifth kingdom�s dissolution. The Larankarha wouldn�t conquer outside of the Endioka river valley again until the 15th century.
	}
	G72_stream_of_the_endioka = {
	    trade_efficiency = 0.1 #The Endioka, literally meaning the Great River, is, alongside the Kalavend and the Vyech, one of the most important rivers of Taychend. Enlarmai, which is situated near the source of the Endioka, has always had commercial connections downstream, most notably in Clematar where Enlarmai merchants often use the Clematari as middlemen between them and the Kheionai.
	}
	G72_the_goldclad_nemesis = {
	    leader_siege = 1 #While Enlarmai has traditionally been the strongest Larankarha city, their total dominance of the Endioka river valley has always been challenged by their greatest rival, Urvand. This rivalry peaked during the Fifth Age of Ambition, where the two cities were embroiled in a century-long war over dominance of the Endioka river valley. In 1419, Enlarmai would finally conquer Urvand after an impressively quick siege of the highland city, crowning their long-awaited victory by murdering the royal family of Urvand. It seemed like Enlarmai would finally manage to assert full dominance over the Larankarha and be able to declare the eighth kingdom of Larankar and finally look southwards again like Seronraha had done.
	}
	G72_erankars_scar = {
	    same_culture_advisor_cost = -0.15 #However, before Enlarmai was able to conquer Clematar and declare the eighth kingdom of Larankar, an unexpected twist of fate occurred. A child of the ruling dynasty of Urvand, Erankar Kaonrippavar, had managed to escape his family�s purge and was now the leader of one of the most renowned mercenary bands of Taychend. Erankar would come back to his homeland, destroying the rising Enlarmai, sacking the shining city and declaring the eighth kingdom, this time with Urvand as the capital. This would forever mark the culture of the Enlarmai, due to two things : the rulers of the Larankarha had always been the Enlarmai, and the declaration of the eighth kingdom by Urvand marked the end of this dominance, and the people feared that the city would experience the same fate as the Ruin Cities after its sacking by Erankar. When the eighth kingdom of Larankar came crashing down, Enlarmai became independent again, but it secluded itself from the rest of the world, becoming an hermit kingdom.
	}
	G72_coming_back_to_reality = {
	    garrison_size = 0.2
 		global_spy_defence = 0.2 #The fact that Enlarmai had managed to stay independent as an hermit kingdom for a century in wartorn Taychend had been a miracle, only made possible by the relative weakness of their neighbors. However, this peaceful isolation would be broken by an invasion by Nanru Nakar in 1698, which resulted in Enlarmai�s subjugation. The subjugation would act as a cold come back to reality for Enlarmai, as they realized the importance of the military they had been neglecting � they had grown weak in complacency, as the minor bandit kings and small-scale incursions were easily dealt with. When the Nakari came, with an army nearly 50,000 strong, they had no answer. The subjugation would be broken after a few decades in 1734 by the military hero Jalinpan Vadula the Liberator, who was subsequently crowned king of Enlarmai. Jalinpan did not only implement many military reforms, building and maintaining fortifications at the borders of the kingdom, he also set himself to the arduous task of reforming the culture of Enlarmai. Vice would be replaced with virtue, complacency with vigilance. All foreign influences, or things associated with foreigners, were purged, from Kheionai-esque philosophies to Cannorian technology.  By Jalinpan Vadula�s death in 1777, Enlarmai was once again an impenetrable fortress, and a kingdom to be feared.
	}
}

	B80_ex_aleceria_ad_necevitas = { # Ex Aleceria Ad Necevitas. (From Wesdam to Neckcliff) Old Damerian expression that references Windtower�s domain within the republic. The expression remained even after Windtower expanded beyond Wesdam and Neckcliff.
		ae_impact = -0.1
	}
	
	B80_legacy_of_the_luminaries = { # Legacy of the Luminaries. During the first war of the Cerulean League, Windtower (then known as Carmeris) managed to remove the threat of Redfort diplomatically and even convinced it to join the league later on. When the Damerian Republic needed a diplomatically focused Luminary, a Carmeri was often elected to the position.
		diplomatic_reputation = 1
	}
	
	B80_the_windward_district = { # The Windward District. A district of Docksbridge with a large number of drydock and construction companies. It was one of the main places where ships were built during the early days of the Damerian Republic. Using wood from the Deruwren forest, the district makes durable ships capable of taking more damage than other Damesheadic ships.
		ship_durability = 0.05
	}
	
	B80_the_silversea_temple = { # The Silversea Temple. A temple found in Windtower and center of a variant of the cults of Munas and The Dame found in most of the West Dameshead. It has a particular focus on the study of celestial bodies for astrology and celestial navigation. The temple focuses on the The Dame as a goddess of knowledge and magic, with the role of goddess of harvest taken by Meris, a minor deity originating from the region Lencori past.
		dip_tech_cost_modifier = -0.05
		trade_steering = 0.1
	}
	
	B80_the_windtower = { # The Windtower. History of the country namesake. Start as an old Lencori temple dedicated to Merisse (goddess of Wind). As the Eidoueni faith died out and the number of mages exploded thanks to the DoAS, it became a repository of magical knowledge and the base of operation of the Silverwind Order (an order of mage created in the Damerian republic to teach magic) and later the Magisterium in the West Dameshead.
		advisor_cost = -0.1
	}
	
	B80_the_sea_tourney = { # The Sea Tourney. Tourney in Windtower happens on the sea instead of on land with water jousts and naval mock battles. The largest of these competitions is the Windtower Great Sea Tourney. These tourneys are great occasions for both captains and crews to prove their skills.
		navy_tradition = 1
	}
	
	B80_who_commands_the_wind_commands_the_sea = { # Who Commands the Wind, Commands the Sea. Windtower uses magic to create favorable conditions for sailing and dominate the sea from the Good Winds Ritual before the DoAS to training and taking conjurers specialized in raising winds and storms on its fleets in modern times.
		naval_morale_damage = 0.1
	}
}

		production_efficiency = 0.1 #The riches of our lands are meant for Amadia, and we give our lands a gilded sheen of gold and iron. Our great cities are beautiful!
	}

		interest = -0.5 #Amadians face a brunt fact: they are behind the times in the world. One thing they do have is money. Thus, Amadians are forgiving with their loans, knowing that everything will make a profit anyways, and helps increase business in the country.

	}

	start = {
		infantry_power = 0.15
		yearly_corruption = -0.1
	}

	bonus = {
		years_of_nationalism = -5
	}

	trigger = {
		tag = S84 #Bwa Dakinshi
		religion = transmutative_path
	}

	free = yes

	S84_baptized_by_blood_and_bronze = {
		army_tradition_decay = -0.01
	}
	
	S84_rejuvenation_of_the_realm = {
		build_cost = -0.15
	}
	
	S84_warlords_no_longer = {
		land_forcelimit_modifier = 0.15
		all_estate_loyalty_equilibrium = 0.05
	}
	
	S84_of_beasts_and_guns = {
		fire_damage = 0.1
	}
	
	S84_to_look_inside_yourself = {
		missionaries = 1
		global_missionary_strength = 0.01
	}
	
	S84_dreams_of_dominion = {
		province_warscore_cost = -0.15
	}
	
	S84_gold_for_knowledge = {
		mil_tech_cost_modifier = -0.1
	}
}

        cavalry_power = 0.2

        tag = R96
    }
    
    free = yes

        tolerance_own = 1
        development_cost_in_primary_culture = -0.1
    }

    R96_comprehensive_drilling = {
        adm_tech_cost_modifier = -0.1
    }

    R96_honorable_few = {
        years_of_nationalism = -5
    }

    R96_army_of_wargs = {
        cav_to_inf_ratio = 0.25
        cavalry_cost = -0.1
    }

        movement_speed = 0.1
        global_trade_goods_size_modifier = 0.05

        monarch_admin_power = 1

    }
}

#Tarakar ideas
M04_ideas = {
	trigger = { tag = M04 }
    free = yes

    start = {
		infantry_power = 0.10
		available_province_loot = 0.50
    }
    bonus = {
		reduced_liberty_desire_on_other_continent = 15
    }

    M04_mountains_dont_give_back_what_they_take = {
	#codified wartime rules for acceptance of surrender, fair treatment of captives, ensuring places can rebuild to be looted again the next time, etc, all in a pragmatic approach to maximize looting and tributes. Lets people know they�ll be treated fairly if they just pay tribute -�take from the strong, let the weak grow strong, and then take from them too�
		ae_impact = -0.15
    }
    M04_the_unchained = {
	#dark dwarovar skirmishes have given rise to a fighting style that doesn�t rely on sight, which has been perfected into a true martial art used with blindfolds by a fanatical order devoted to Dookan. Their greatest blademasters gouges out their own eyes to rely solely on Dookan�s sight in a show of devotion, and others orcs fear them as they can seemingly predict any opponent�s moves
		discipline = 0.05
		tolerance_own = 1
    }
	M04_the_true_treasure = {
	#heavy emphasis on familial bonds, with the primary duty of orcish parents being the upbringing of the young. Children are spared from the savagery that war and plunder brings, giving them the opportunity to understand both aspects of Dookan: peace, and war. Unlike hobgoblins, the traditional family unit matters a lot here
		global_unrest = -2
    }
    M04_rule_of_the_fittest = {
	#the strong should rule, and orcs rule because they are the strongest. The practice of Ozarm�chadash evolved into a form of gladiatorial combat, turning it from a way to settle disputes to a way to earn status and legitimacy. Anyone can enter the arena, and even dwarves and goblins can earn higher status by risking their lives in combat
		army_tradition = 0.5
		manpower_in_true_faith_provinces= 0.10
    }
	M04_improvise_adapt_overcome = {
	#both dwarves and goblins are characterized by ruinous vanity projects and massive waste of resources at the expense of their own people. We orcs always had to make do with what we had, and we learned to be efficient. The legacy of the Dwarovar will be repurposed towards useful ends, and never shall we build solely out of pride; this is why Tarakar will never meet the same end as Aul-Dwarov did.
		global_regiment_cost = -0.10
		build_cost = -0.1
	}
	M04_end_of_the_clans  = {
	#to become Tarakar�s ruler, one must destroy all obstacles on their way. To rule Tarakar is to rule unchallenged. Gone are the days when we were a mere union of bickering tribes. The realm shall be reformed into a modern state, one that knows only one authority.
		max_absolutism_effect = 0.15
    }
    M04_breaking_the_cage = {
	#worship of Dookan has traditionally been very ritualistic and decentralized. With a modernizing nation comes modernizing doctrine, and standardizing Dookan�s worship into holy scriptures. Freeing a god is not something that can be done by mortal steel ; Dookan�s cage shall be broken by making the followers of the traitor gods turn away from them to weaken their power. Only then shall their treachery be undone, and it�s our scholars that will be our fighters in the greatest of all conflicts!
		missionaries = 1
		enforce_religion_cost = -0.5 
    }
}

	}

When the Castanorian invaded, they built roads and laid the foundation of Aenawick to facilitate their control over the region. Now they are gone while the spirit of Milcorissia remains.
		hostile_attrition = 1
	}
	
	B85_say_not_his_name = { # Say Not His Name. Story of Xamarzu, of how the Castanorian destroyed many labyrinth-catacomb hoping to destroy his phylactery and banned the usage of his name, becoming a superstition for the Milcorissian and Arannese.
		global_unrest = -2
	}
	
	B85_nerat_flames = { # Nerat�s Flames. Varlosen produces candles known to last longer than most. These candles are used by neratic priests when starting the funeral rites. If the rites end after the candle goes out, the dead will found themself lost in Nerat�s domain
		production_efficiency = 0.1
	}
	
	B85_find_the_cure = { # To Find The Cure. When the White Pestilence ravaged Cannor, it was in the tower of Varlosen that Garion the Wise worked to find a cure, hidden from Canrec by the magic tower. After the end of the WP, Varlosen remained a place of study of magical plagues and many more cures were created in the tower.
		global_manpower_modifier = 0.15
		mages_loyalty_modifier = 0.05
	}
	
	B85_pact_of_salt = { # Pact of Salt. The rulers of Varlorsen made a pact with a secret organization named the Lodge of the Nameless. At first a group of necromancers, it attracted practitioners of other forbidden art (blood mage, cultist, demon worshiping gnoll�). The ruler of Valorsen protects the lodge, ensuring its anonymity, in exchange the lodge shares its power with them.
		all_power_cost = -0.025
	}
	
	B85_eternal_guard = { # Eternal Guard. Statues of soldiers can be found in the forest of Varlosen. People are buried next to them, as the statues protect the bodies of the dead. Sometimes a statue vanishes, or a new one appears. It is explained as Nerat recalling a guard or bringing a new one to stand watch.
		stability_cost_modifier = -0.15
	}
	
	B85_undying_faith = { # Undying Faith. The Lodge of the Nameless are followers of the Milcorissian Mortuary cult that revered Nerat and his chosen, the Milcorissian Lich-kings. Followers of the faith believe that the state of the soul is linked to the state of the body, and once it rot, the soul rot with it. The Lodge seeks to restore the faith to the Border and allow the return of its rightful ruler.
		tolerance_heathen = 1
		global_missionary_strength = 0.01
	}
}

#Dolontugiin 
V02_ideas = { 
	start = { 
		diplomatic_reputation = 1 #Kept its independence while sandwiched between the Cheqh�anate and Guwamuud. 
		manpower_in_true_faith_provinces = 0.15 #The federation is concerned with keeping its independence and fighting the Facestealers. 
	} 
	 
	bonus = { 
		missionaries = 1 #With the discovery of the Mirror of Nothingness, the Order of the Golden Mask finally accepts to take a more proactive approach towards Facestealers and begin proselytizing as their theology starts to focus on bringing people to the Supreme Spirit. 
	} 
	 
	trigger = { 
		tag = V02 #Dolontugiin 
	} 
	free = yes 
 
 
	V02_the_seven_banners = { 
		land_forcelimit_modifier = 0.15 #The nation of Dolontugiin, meaning Seven Banner Confederacy in Runsukhi, originated during the 900s with the rise of the Oinukhudi Cheqh�anate. Before then, the northern monasteries of the Runsukhi had next to no political unity, but the threat near their borders forced them to gather their forces. The federation traditionally held all the Runsukhi lands north of the Cangji plateau and largely managed to keep its independence, although it often fell into the spheres of influence of the Cheqh�anate or Guwamuud. The ruler of the federation, the High Officer, takes care of military (which mostly consists of protecting against Facestealers due to the collapse of both the Cheqh�anate and Guwamuud) and diplomatic matters, with much of the administration being handled by the individual monasteries. The seven main monasteries that make up the federation have to give men to participate in the united army, whose subdivisions are the eponymous Seven Banners. Recently, the three westernmost monasteries, the Monastery of Iron (Guushuush), the Monastery of Sandstone (Sandstone Ridge) and the Monastery of Bronze (Huujoolgin) have been lost to Khezhagak�s rise, leaving a big hit in the federation�s legitimacy. (Dolontugiin could start with cores on Khezhagak?) 
	} 
	V02_weaving_the_wastes = { 
		movement_speed = 0.15 #Dolontugiin has a particularly close relationship with the Lowland Runsukhi, due to the decentralized nature of the federation and the distance separating its monasteries. Their activities as middlemen, envoys and warriors form the glue for the federation�s continued existence, and in exchange they are protected by the Seven Banners, each of their migratory caravans being assigned groups of soldiers trained in abjuration. 
	} 
	V02_the_hidden_heart = { 
		prestige = 1 #Before the Day of Ashen Skies, the lands that now comprise Dolontugiin were the heartlands of the Khantaar civilization. Now covered by ash and sand, the great cities of the Khantaar bear witness to the long history of the wastes, researched and preserved by the monks of Dolontugiin. These cities are also filled with ancient magical relics. 
	} 
   	V02_the_ashen_geomancers = { 
		defensiveness = 0.15 #Over years of contacts and mutual influence between the Khudi and Dolontugiin, some of the former�s traditions have seeped into those of the northern Runsukhi. Most notable is the art of geomancy, which has been adapted by the Runsukhi to ward off entire areas from spirits rather than harmonize with them through precise abjuration patterns formed by symbols, objects and buildings. The Ashen Geomancers of Dolontugiin are renowned throughout Kashaalg and have taken part in the construction of many monasteries to help protect them. 
	} 
	V02_the_buried_monasteries = { 
		build_cost = -0.1 #By combining the warding powers of Ashen Geomancy and the ancient defenses of the Khantaar cities, the Runsukhi have been able to reclaim two ruined Khantaar cities in the 13th century, which became monasteries under the jurisdiction of the Monastery of Salt and the Monastery of Wine respectively. This represented a great advancement for the Runsukhi, as it started the movement to reclaim their ancient cities from the Facestealers and allowed them to search the cities much more efficiently. 
	} 
	V02_order_of_the_golden_mask = { 
		tolerance_own = 2 #The Order of the Golden Mask is a sect of Levajaan monks that exist outside of the monasteries� boundaries, working as nomad rider monks with a close relationship with the Lowland Runsukhi. They are vehement keepers of tradition and order and are the main force pushing for the complete closing off of the Kashaalg wastes from the Khudi, Shuvuushi and centaur entrances. Over the years, they have placed magical barriers making the entry to the wastes harder and harder. They wear masks made out of gold in reverence of the Death Sheperd, who they believe is a being of pure light. 
	} 
	V02_the_mirror_of_nothingness = { 
		morale_damage = 0.1 #Found in 1673 (date not set in stone at all) in the city where the Monastery of Wine can be found, the Mirror of Nothingness is a powerful artifact with immense spirit-binding capabilities, taking the form of a round, polished surface of cracked onyx with a diameter of approximately 5 meters which reflects faces that only exist in the Spirit Plane. When looking at the Mirror of Nothingness, pure dread takes over the observer and a sensation that your head is slowly being eaten from the inside, which is said to be the feeling of your spirit being sucked away. It is very effective against Facestealers, who appear to be drawn by the Mirror instead of fearing it, and will simply fade away over time, although the Runsukhi haven�t been able to replicate its magic. 
	} 
}

#Oktikheion (reworked by takasaki, original by runehawk)

		recover_navy_morale_speed = 0.1 # get their ass kicked all the time, always come back
    }

		tag = G47
    }
    free = yes

    G47_the_fractious_kheion = { # Oktikheion has always been a fractious city. During the Isolation after the first Deathwinds came, most Kheions suffered infighting and civil wars, but � probably � none suffered more than Oktikheion. Next to no records of the city�s history in this time survive, as each petty tyrant or mob-king who arose attempted to erase any mention of their predecessor from history, some even using enchantment magic to erase them from memory as well. While the other Kheions divested of their monarchies without much bloodshed after the First League War, Oktikheion�s last king instead plunged the city into a civil war, and was only defeated by the intervention of Arpedif�r. Since then, the city has moved variously between mob-democracy, oligarchy, plutocracy and even military or naval tyranny, as groups of citizens in the �Fractious Kheion� move from one political fancy to the other. Though one would think this as a sign of political radicalism, in truth the Okt�bhen care little for what sort of republican government rules them, only that it rules well, and allows them to get on with their lives. And when they don�t? Well, a revolution can be great fun, if you�re not the one being overthrown.
		candidate_random_bonus = 1 # have to be good to survive politics
    }
    G47_teachings_of_melosdales = { # The Okt�bhen were the first Kheionai to taste the sweetness of sugar, and they quickly came to love it, especially amidst a Kaydano storm, cultivating vast plantations of sugarcane in and around their kheion�s walls. For three centuries, the Okt�bhen�s obsession with sugar remained just that � but one day in the decades after the fall of the monarchy, with the city�s future still uncertain, an elf named Mel�sdales would seek to interrogate that obsession. He pioneered a school of philosophy known as Mel�sdalism, that holds the pursuit of pleasure � of both body, mind, and heart � as the thing that drives all life. To Mel�sdalists, pleasure is a liberating and empowering force, that allows one to numb the senses to pain, as well as excite the senses. Overtime, Mel�sdalism would become the driving philosophy of Oktikheion, as its citizens enjoyed the fruits of physicality, nature, and culture. An offshoot school, founded by the mage Cyrevindales, would even take this idea into the realm of the arcane as well, arguing for the use of illusion and enchantment magic to enhance one�s experience of the world, and broaden the possibilities for pleasure.
		idea_cost = -0.05 
		global_unrest = -1
    }
    G47_the_first_triakos = { # Sandwiched between two powerful states, and In search of more defensible land to exploit following the First League War, Oktikheion were the first to look to the water for expansion opportunities. First colonising the islands off Kimanis, even these lands proved inadequate, and as time went on Oktikheion�s ships braved farther and farther into the Cleaved Sea, until finally they discovered Devand in 469. Though the city would be robbed of the prestige of founding the first colony, Oktikheion still profited greatly off of both the founding of Keyol�on, as well as the further expansion of their nascent island empire. To protect these overseas holdings, Oktikheion would spearhead the creation of the Tri�kaupos � the Tri�kos, plural Tri�kes, for short � a small but manoeuvrable vessel with three rows of oars and a sturdy, angular ram at the forefront. With these Tri�kes, Oktikheion would dominate the cleaved sea during the centuries between the First Eneid and the rise of Ormam. They did not stop there, however, and Okt�bhen naval innovation would lead to the creation of yet larger and heavier ships, with the D�ikakaupos being said to be so large as to require 10 oarsmen per oar.
		dip_tech_cost_modifier = -0.05  # naval innovators
		navy_tradition = 0.5 # built first trireme
    }
    G47_low_brow_high_culture = { # To the Okt�bhen, the distinctions between high and low culture, or the three pleasures of Mel�sdales, are made to be blurred. Their raucous comedies are filled with both base innuendo of every type imaginable and incisive socio-political satire and commentary. Their music, dancing, and epic poetry excites the heart and senses with stories of both the purer and baser aspects of love � an fitting companion to the more sensual offerings of the city. At the famous Metis�ran Games competitions of raw strength, gymnastic skill, physical beauty and magical and martial ability are attended by the pre-eminent men and women of not only Oktikheion, but the entire Kheionai world. With this in mind then it is no surprise that the Okt�bhen would become obsessed with the Orinthaira, a class of the most sought after courtesans in all Andeios. The Orinthaira are able to blend good company in a banquet or bed, with sharp wit, song and dance, assure self confidence and intelligent conversation � usually being better read than their clientele. The foremost amongst them are even able to command both considerable influence over preeminent political figures and a very, very high price.
		diplomatic_reputation = 1
		female_advisor_chance = 0.25
    }
    G47_the_thamasthaltus = { # When Oktikheion was ensnared under the unprecedented Ormabhen Hegemony from the late 9th to 10th centuries, they chafed under Ormam�s insufferable dominion, especially outraged by Ormam�s �purchase� of Anis�kheion in 973. Oktikheion, allying with Arpedif�r, embarked on an ambitious naval expansion program, paid for with the gold mines of Althung�ti. However, instead of trying to match Ormam�s expansive fleets, they invested in a new force of marine infantry, the Thamasthalt�s, or sea turtles, drawn from the unwanted sons of the Orinthaira and named for their green cloaks and heavy armour � an ironic name, as that armour meant they could not swim. With this new force Oktikheion and Arpedif�r challenged Ormam�s naval supremacy in the First Great Sea War, from 981 to 1016. Though they were defeated, the success of the famous Amadian Expedition in the 1030s allowed them to rebuild their broken fleet with a wealth of silver and damestear, and they finally broke Ormam�s power in the Second Great Sea War from 1056 to 1071. Though Degakheion prevented Oktikheion from replacing Ormam as Alecand�s hegemon, the Thamasthalt�s remained a force to be reckoned with in the following centuries.
		naval_morale_damage = 0.1 # marines go hard at sea 	 
		allowed_marine_fraction = 0.25
    }
    G47_the_great_orinthaira_revolt = { # At the Battle of Sere�stina in 1391, Oktikheion�s army was routed by the Eltibhar. In the legendary failure of the Second Amadia Expedition in 1397, only a single ship returned, the rest destroyed by a stray Deathwind. The seizure of Kimanis in the 1440s gave hope � until subsequent tension with Degakheion led to the Battle at Astoli�n, Where their army was ambushed and annihilated. A hastily raised force of conscripts was mauled outside Kimanis, then the city itself fell. However, as Oktikheion�s sons were sent to die in disaster after disaster, the city�s blustering leadership still refused to give in � and so the Orinthaira took action. One night in 1480, the Orinthaira seized half the Okt�bhen political elite as they slept beside them, holding them hostage with the aid of their sons in the Thamasthalt�s. Demanding an end to the war, and rights for themselves, Oktikheion had no choice but to acquiesce. Given full political rights alongside wealthy � and unmarried � women, the Orinthaira became, in opposition to Kheionai custom, an openly powerful political force in the city, passing their business and property to their daughters and sending their sons to the Thamasthalt�s.
		advisor_cost = -0.1
    }
    G47_o_happy_city_unhappy_at_peace = { # �O� happy city, why so unhappy at peace?� � Lady Vesike, in Thalanthanes�s �The Prick of Pike�. After the fall of the Degabhen Hegemony, a Second En�id descended on Alecand. It was a time of prosperity, economic growth, and cultural splendour � and for Oktikheion, it was a time of deep restlessness. Unlike the other kheions, in Degakheion only a Phylaxiate enjoys the rights of a citizen, leaving over 80% of the city disenfranchised. 	G46_the_erythe = { # The Driv�s Eryth�, or Red Path, more simply called the Eryth�, is a strict training regimen all children born to Phylaxana families undergo, male and female. Some dreams are common to all: to be devoured by wild beasts, to be burnt alive, to starve or thirst to death. Others are tailored. To hear your loved ones scream as they burn beneath flaming rubble you cannot displace, to live again your worst mistakes and deepest regrets. 	G46_degabhen_wit = { # One of the things the Degabhen are known for above all is �Degabhen Wit�, a tendency towards curt, terse, but smart phrases. Personal moderation, and thus conciseness when speaking, is a sign of virtue, for a wasteful warrior is a poor one. So it goes with the other base pleasures of life � drink, good food, sex, rest and relaxation. The enjoyment of these desires is normal � the restraint of them virtuous./n/nAnd for the Karkares?
