#Lokemeion Ideas (reworked by Blaziy and Takasaki, original by runehawk)
G49_ideas = {
	start = {
		advisor_cost = -0.1 #They’re a bunch of scholars
		reduced_liberty_desire = 15 #Shared with everyone so they can deal with their nekhei(s)
	}
	bonus = {
		global_monthly_devastation = -0.02 #We’re the furthest away from the deathwinds so we aren’t affected as much
	}
	trigger = {
		tag = G49
	}
	free = yes

	G49_the_grand_library = { #We have a giant library with a whole bunch of knowledge that we’ve collected over the years. Library of Alexandria vibes. The Library dominates the city’s fortified inner district, the Oúraskheion, with its vaults and archives stretching deep underground. Most curiously, however, over the years more and more governmental institutions have been moved within its walls. The old great reading room for example forms the meeting chamber for the Lokebhen assembly, while the Kylakas’ office – once that of the Scholar King – sits within the prison warden’s old private study. While the merger of government and Library has led to parts of the facility falling into disrepair – with many scholars privately complaining that there are increasingly fewer places to actually study – it nonetheless shows just how vital the Grand Library is to Lokemeion.
		idea_cost = -0.1
	}
	G49_scholar_kings = { #In the past, our nation was ruled by a series of ‘Scholar Kings', wise men who dedicated much of their lives in the pursuit of knowledge. Though long gone, the spirit of the scholar kings has remained within our people. In every field of research you are guaranteed to find a great number of Lokemeioni citizens, which in turn means that the state has a vast pool of talent to draw from when looking for new staff
		advisor_pool = 2
		female_advisor_chance = 0.25
	}
	G49_the_city_of_law = { # An early Scholar-King of Lokemeion called Denarthoros created the first true legal system among the Kheionai during the Isolation, leading to Lokemeion maintaining peace and good order more easily. While in the other Kheions, law was often arbitrary and malleable, and the dispensers of justice were mostly indisputable, leading to judicial tyranny, thanks to Denathoros Lokemeion developed a system of legal precedence in terms of substantive law and a contested trial of guilt or innocence, with a jury selected by sortition. Though these reforms would gradually be adopted elsewhere, the Lokebhen maintain the strongest legal tradition in the Kheionai world with a significant portion of the Grand Library’s archives dedicated to maintaining detailed records of legal procedures and trials, dating back to Denarthoros’ reforms. Perhaps the most famous Lokebhen trial in Kheionai history was that of Ivranax the Devourer, where the lawyer Pelodinorus, later elected Kylakas, successfully prosecuted a fiend of the Infernal Planes for contract violations.
		global_autonomy = -0.05
	}
	G49_forget_and_fall = { #”Forget and Fall” is a common phrase in Lokemeion meaning that one should never forget the past, for those who do are doomed to fall into the servitude of history. The Lokebhen are known produce the most prestigious historians, with each one generally able to name most every detail of every significant historian event in Kheionai history – and many details from the histories of other lands and peoples as well. They are not just interested in recording the past, however. Embodied by Archatirades, an explorer, historian and philosopher who would create the first general Andeiosian history in the ninth century, and along with it refine Lokemeion’s guiding philosophy into the singular Archatiradism, Lokebhen historians as extremely interested in discussing and dissecting the past for its meaning, taking lessons from the past into the present, and attempting to live life and solve problems with the wisdom of the ancients in mind.
		free_adm_policy = 1
	}
	G49_protector_of_the_grand_library = { #Chained to the Grand Library is the soul of an elf known as ‘The Protector’. While generally acting as a strict librarian, ensuring the maintenance and sanctity the library deserves, The Protector is rumored to have much more power, most notably when they seemingly managed to sway Eltikan’s army from touching the library after the capture of the city in 1456. They also like to talk about the ‘good ol’ days’ and ‘that damned pirate’. Whenever a new book, scrolls, or related is brought to the library they’ll take it, make and give you a copy, and keep the original - though they only did the second part after much complaining.
		innovativeness_gain = 0.5
	}
	G49_cannorian_resistance = { #When the Cannorians and other outsiders came, many kheionai, like Ormam or our own Nekhei of Besolaki, quickly adopted their technology and ideas, but we did not. Our past is important to us and we were not going let it be overtaken by some outsiders. Lokemeion held onto their traditions and fought against Cannorian influence, and it would be from Lokemeion that the first Kheionist answers to Ravelianism and the Thought would be made,
		tolerance_own = 2
	}
	G49_eltibhar_enlightenment = { # Archatirades is famous for his compilation of the first Universal Andeiosian History, that attempted to look at all peoples of Andeios, not just the Kheionai. Archatirades – and the future Archatiradist philosophers and historians who followed him – would attempt to truly understand the way of the Barbhen foreigners, and to document and interrogate their way of life. After all, how could one convince the Barbhen of the errors of their societies, and the superiority of the Kheionai way, unless they understand the Barbhen’s errors? It would be with Archatiradist texts that Ameion would find an intellectual basis for Kheionisation, and when the Kheiosian League conquered the west side of the island in the early 1800s, and integrated the Eltibhar into their nascent empire, Lokemeion were the first of the Kheionai to truly try and learn about them and integrate them into Kheionai society. (Should have a pompous “we’re better then them” attutude/we’re in the right for cultural genociding them)
		culture_conversion_time = -0.25
	}
}

#Kherka Ideas (reworked by Blaziy and Takasaki, original by Runehawk)
G48_ideas = {
	start = {
		production_efficiency = 0.1 #Their forges are really good
		reduced_liberty_desire = 15 #Shared with everyone so they can deal with their nekhei(s)
	}
	bonus = {
		prestige = 1 #Has longstanding rivalries with Eltikan and Mteibhara later on between the quality of their forging, but Kherka always manages to stay on top
	}
	trigger = {
		tag = G48
	}
	free = yes

	
	G48_the_forge_council = { #Over the years, the kheion with perhaps the most consistently popular and democratic government is Kherka. The first known republic to be established after the Ruin, the Forge Council is comprised of 5 members of each of the great Forge-Clans, elected by their peers, with the Kylakas elected and sustained in office by majority vote within the council. While the council is not exactly the same as it was during the Isolation, the Forge Council they created lives on stronger than ever. Furthermore, any person can join the council as long as they have their forge-clan’s support, and any councilmember can become Kylakas with the council’s support, with many Kylakas’ being former blacksmiths, merchants, or even a comedian at one point. Despite the changes over the years, two things have stayed the same, the Forge Council rules Kherka, and their people will never accept anything else.
		candidate_random_bonus = 1
	}
	G48_the_ten_clans_of_kherka = { #Descended from the ten leaders of the initial miner’s revolt that led to the establishment of the Kherkan republic, the ten forge-clans of Kherka have dominated life in the city since the first Deathwind. All citizens of Kherka are either born as a member of one of the clans or marry into one, with the forge-clans providing key networks of patronage and support. Each forge-clan also has its own identity and rough geographic domain, electing five members from within their own ranks that they send to the forge council. They are known for their competitiveness, and the city’s many festivals are often based around competition between the smiths and craftsmen of the clans, most notably the [forged in fire] festival, where the Forge-Clans compete to see who can make the strongest suit of armour.  
		build_time = -0.15
	}
	G48_the_kherkan_league = { #In 354 the first league war broke out between the Kherkan and Degabhen Leagues which eventually saw Kherka the winner. Using their mastery of bronzeworking, Kherka outfitted powerful heavy troops during the war. When they discovered that their ally Arpedifer had used a powerful new formation, the Phalanx, to fend off the Degabhen League, they eagerly sent them shipments of heavy bronze armour and shields, slipping them past the Kheions through enemy territory and ensuring Arpedifer’s survival – at the same time, they began to adopt the Phalanx themselves, the second Kheion to do so, and would use their advantage in arms and armour to break the Degabhen warriors at the Fourth Battle of Agholor.
		infantry_power = 0.1
	}	
	G48_forges_of_war = { #Master metalworkers, they use their mineral wealth and internal competitiveness to increase their productivity in a variety of fields in normal times – when Kherka goes to war, however, they turn all of their forges to the task, producing great weapons and armour that allow them to outfit their armies. Kherka were both the first among the Kheionai to rediscover how to create bronze, with their natural supplies of tin and copper, and were also the first to truly refine steel production thanks to their control of Sidlar’s iron – these advantages give them more experience in armour working than any other Kheion.
		global_regiment_cost = -0.1
	}
	G48_the_great_holdout = { #With our mines on Metei being so far away from Kherka’s Kheion as well as the unpredictability of the deathwinds, it’s not too uncommon for the miners to unexpectedly be hit by a deathstorm while there, leaving them stuck in the mines for upwards of a year. In 1481 Kherka was forced to sign a treaty with Lokemeion that saw their government flee to Anisikheion, leaving their city as a Lokemeion puppet state for the next 60 years. When the miners heard of this they immediately declared the mines off-limits to the new Kherkan puppet government and managed to ward off all attempts to retake the mines for 7 years until they were crushed. Later became known as The Great Holdout
		global_supply_limit_modifier = 0.25
	}
	G48_kherkan_made = { #Set up the first independent gun makers among the Kheionai, exported Kherkan made rifles across the world.
		fire_damage = 0.1
	}
	G48_the_alecand_branch = { #When the Gommo first came to our shores, we quickly accepted them and helped them set up a Gommo Branch here. Since then they introduced us to the concept of artificery, something we quickly adopted into our forging
		trade_efficiency = 0.1
	}
}

#Orenvalyam
U39_ideas = {
    start = {
		land_forcelimit_modifier = 0.33 # hordes of peasants and freed-slaves

    }
    bonus = {
		governing_capacity_modifier = 0.15 # kavalali system helps govern territory
    }
    trigger = {
		tag = U39 # Orenvalyam
    }
    free = yes

    U39_the_coming_of_the_dawn = { # When the Jaherian Exemplars arrived, sharing the Cult of Vherenar’s abolitionist beliefs, but also bringing the dark news of the death of all Great-Gods save one, the Cult of Vherenar knew instantly that they could not simply wait for the destruction of evil, but must bring it about themselves. The last of the Elusive Ones, Nayiru, had sent Taychend the heralds of a new age, but the Cult of Vherenar alone could bring it about. And so the Oren Nayiru were born, the Cult of the One Sun.\n\nFrom there, their religion quickly descended into a spiral of radicalism, railing against monarchy, tyranny, foreign invaders, and above all slavery. The Oren Nayiru advocated a revolutionary transformation of society, with the Kavalali, warlord-priests, as the tip of the spear that would bring the Coming of the Dawn – liberation from darkness – to every living being on the planet. This religious fervour would drive the Kavalali and the faith as a whole, and the Oren Nayiru would never give up proselytising its message to everyone who could hear it.
		missionaries = 1
    }
    U39_no_voice_shackled = { # Only a tyrant rules alone. Though individual Kavalali are trusted in their own communities to lead in political and spiritual matters, and the High Kavalali are trusted to rule over their cells’ area of control, the Oren Nayiru had always believed that there must be some sort of faith-wide body that controlled the actions of its members, and therefore guided the Oren Nayiru in the true direction. Inspired by the senate-like Valhathikutta of the southern cities, and the ancient Pantacuttam – “wide gatherings” of Kalavendhi warriors – the Kavalakuttam, “the Circle of Kalavali”, came to fill this purpose.\n\nOriginally, the Kavalakuttam was an informal institution, essentially a “government of letters”. Carried along the underground network of communication between the High Kavalali, the leaders of the Oren Nayiru constantly challenged and debated each others religious positions and military and political actions, aiming to hold each other to account as best they could. After the arrival of Dawn, it was hoped the transformation of this informal network to a single formal legislature would be swift and painless. Within the halls of the Kavalakuttam, no voice would be shackled, and Kavalali from every culture and corner of the faith would be represented, freely voting on decisions of importance.
		advisor_pool = 2 
		idea_cost = -0.1
    }
    U39_the_elvenness_of_relics = { # From the perspective of the Kavalali, the relics of the Slaver-Nobles had made their evil clear over the past 1500 years, as warlords used them to impose tyrannical regimes and empires on the people, and untold millions were crushed beneath their power. When combined with the belief, widespread in Andeiosian philosophy, that magic originates first and foremost from living beings, the doctrine of the Elvenness of Relics came naturally. The Slaver-Nobles, as myth and archaeology tell plainly, built their power from the slavery of others – would it be that far-fetched, then, to say that the magical force they imbued their relics with came from slavery as well? The Oren Nayiru believe that relics are ensouled objects, and must be treated as such – though it may be necessary, as it was with the Armour of Yodhan, to wield them in the defence and advancement of the faith, the immoral nature of their creation cannot be forgotten. To the Oren Nayiru relics must be treated with the utmost respect, and the new so-called “science” of Artificery and the foreign relic-trade intertwined with it must be cracked down on.
   	 mages_loyalty_modifier = 0.1
	 stability_cost_modifier = -0.15
    }
    U39_flash_in_the_barrel_light_in_the_dark = { # Without the military might of Ameion, or the relics of the warlords, to help them, it was no wonder that the Kavalali would turn to a new hope from the east to secure their power – gunpowder. Armed originally by Rezankand, the Oren Nayiru invested significantly into matchlock weaponry, quickly learning how to build their own gunsmithies, and establishing elite “Matchlock Banners”, who would wield the concentrated power of Nayiru on the battlefield. To the Oren Nayiru, the matchlock and musket quickly became a great equaliser that would one day carry them to dawn – after all, even the greatest Taychendi warrior or Kheionai hoplite could be felled by a concentrated volley of gunfire. These matchlock troops are accompanied by hordes of light infantry armed with sabre and spear, ensuring that once the enemy battle lines have been withered away by gunfire, they will break when confronted with the charge of Oren’s faithful.
		infantry_power = 0.1
		land_morale = 0.05
    }
    U39_as_sun_conquers_night = { # “And we shall sweep over the world like sun conquers night.” So said Elrandar Silverspite, as he raised his sword to the Eclipse, and began the great war for Dawn. The Kamrayakvalist faction of the Oren Nayiru follow in Silverspite’s footsteps, believing that only a strong, powerful Soldier-Emperor, leading the faith from the front lines, can embark on the global conquest necessary to finally end the cycle of warlordism and bring Nayiru’s light to the rest of the world. The Kamrayakvalists, centred in Uesrennu, find their support among the rank-and-file soldiery, who are constantly pressuring the High Kavalali to throw off their comparatively conservative moderatism – if they could have it their way, they would see the faith totally militarised, the Kavalakuttam sidelined, and the relationship between High Kavalali and Kamrayakval redefined in the latter’s favour. After all, as the Kavalalists say, what better challenge to the pre-existing warlords and tyrants of the world could there be than to raise up a champion of our own?
		manpower_in_true_faith_provinces = 0.20
    }
    U39_keepers_of_truth_guide_our_way = { # The elite High Kavalali have always considered it their sacred duty to keep the Oren Nayiru on the true path, and the High Kavalalist faction believes it is their political duty as well. Though they were once the primary drivers of the faith’s decent into radicalism, once the Oren Nayiru’s direction and beliefs solidified by in the latter half 15th century, and several setbacks and challenges drove the High Kavalali to place the internal stability of the movement over rapid expansion and revolution – when Silverspite led the faith to disaster, it would be the High Kavalali, brutalised by his descent into bloodthirsty paranoia, that would act to save it. With their power centred in the Three Cells of Nanru Nakar, and support drawn from any who was committed to revolution, but unwilling to throw their bodies to the meatgrinder of militaristic madness, the High Kavalalists advocate moderation at home and abroad, hoping to prevent internal chaos while not neglecting the woes of the rest of the world.
		same_religion_advisor_cost = -0.10
		yearly_corruption = -0.05
    }
    U39_one_eye_on_sunrise = { # When Elrandar Silverspite began his War for the Dawn, many among the Oren Nayiru believed that their inevitable victory was finally drawing near. Victory after victory emboldened them, even as the death toll and devastation reached nearly unbearable levels. Then Silverspite fell to madness, and then he fell in battle, and as the remnants of the Oren Nayiru fled back to the shadows, with eight million dead and the faith shattered, they knew it was all for nothing. In the following years, many took aim at the rampant militaristic fervour that had consumed the Oren Nayiru – and so the Monasticists rejected it entirely.\n\nTaking up residence primarily in the hilltop strongholds of the Iron Hills and the Larankarha Highlands, the Monasticists believe that there is no need to launch any wild, expansionistic wars – instead, one can build Nayiru’s paradise in the lands the faith already owns, awaiting Nayiru’s true return at some indeterminate time in the future. This way, the light of the faith can be preserved, without inviting death and devastation like Silverspite did. In the wider Kavalakuttam, the Monasticists argue always for restraint, internal development and a defensive posture.
		build_cost = -0.1
		defensiveness = 0.15
    }
}
